elements.text: For this activity, you will need Pattern Blocks in a variety of colors to use as fall leaves and a book or folder to use as a curtain. You can include colors that might not occur in nature.
The Things That I LOVE About TREES,
we read about how trees change as the seasons change. In the fall, leaves change colors. People like to collect fall leaves and show them off. We also talked about the order of the seasons.

In this activity, I will arrange Pattern Blocks representing fall leaves behind a curtain. I will tell you which color I put first, second, third, and fourth. You will set up your leaves in the same order. Then I will take down my curtain and we can compare our leaves!
Arrange a yellow, orange, green, and red Pattern Block, in that order, behind your curtain.
Can you set up your fall leaves like mine? Here is my order: first is a yellow leaf, second an orange leaf, third a green leaf, and fourth a red leaf.
Ask children to tell which color leaf is first, second, third, and fourth using the sentence frame,
. Raise the curtain to check whether the order of the children’s leaves matches yours.
Continue with new arrangements of up to five Pattern Blocks.
Ask children to use the ordinal terms to describe the leaf orders they recreated. Lead a quick discussion about other instances in which you might use ordinal numbers.

Model placing the leaves in a specific order without the curtain, pointing to each Pattern Block and checking that students match your  arrangement. After children successfully recreate arrangements they can see, continue with the curtain in place.

Have children create an order of leaves with Pattern Blocks behind a curtain. Ask children to describe the order they created using ordinal terms and recreate it behind the curtain. Then compare arrangements.

Before beginning the activity, review the ordinal terms and color names needed to complete the activity. Use visual cues for each term, pointing when possible. As children describe order, encourage them to describe each “leaf” in the way that is most comfortable for them, either by color or shape.

Consider using larger manipulatives, such as colored blocks rather than the Pattern Blocks, to support the fine motor needs of the children in each group. To further hone their skills, you can provide smaller manipulatives like Connecting Cubes or colored beads for children to arrange instead.

For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes or other small manipulatives in four different colors to represent trees.
The Things That I LOVE About TREES,
we read about how beautiful different trees can be. We talked about how when you imagine, you make a picture in your mind. We also thought about the order things happen in.
Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.
In this activity, we will imagine we are arranging four beautiful trees. Each of you will imagine your own order for the trees in your head, then describe it and create it using the Connecting Cubes.
Close your eyes and imagine four trees.

I am imagining four trees lined up. One is the green cube, one is the blue cube, one is the red cube, and one is the black cube. Now I open my eyes and put the red tree first, the green tree second, the blue tree third, and the black tree fourth.
Imagine the four trees in any order you want. Can you put them in that order and describe the order to us?
Continue until each child has arranged four trees and described them using ordinal numbers.
Ask children what kinds of pictures they saw in their heads when imagining the trees. What did they like about using their imaginations?

To simplify the activity, use only three Connecting Cubes to represent trees. Encourage children to describe the trees’ positions as first, second, and third, having them repeat after you if necessary.
After they have arranged the Connecting Cubes, provide children with paper and crayons. Ask children to draw pictures of their four trees in the order they described.

Review the ordinal terms with children before beginning, pointing to the four Connecting Cubes in turn. Also review the names of the colors of each cube you provide. Ensure that students understand the meaning of

For children who appear to lose focus as they wait for their turns, provide them with Connecting Cubes to quietly arrange. Encourage children to listen to each others’ descriptions of trees and to practice organizing trees as they wait.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes in a variety of colors and a book or folder to use as a curtain.
The Things That I LOVE About TREES,

we read about what happens to trees during different times of the year. In spring, there are flowers on the trees. In summer, there are bees near the trees. In fall, the leaves fall to the bottom of the tree, and in winter, there is snow on top of the tree.
Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
In this activity, I will arrange Connecting Cubes behind a curtain. I will tell you how I have set them up. Then you will try to set up yours in the same way.
Lay out a variety of Connecting Cubes. Arrange a brown Connecting Cube on the top of a black cube, hidden behind your curtain.
Can you set up your cubes like mine? I have a brown cube on top of a black cube.
Lift the curtain and compare the arrangements. Discuss any differences between the two. Encourage children to use location words when describing what is different.
Continue with new arrangements of pairs of Connecting Cubes until each child successfully recreates arrangements.
Ask children to identify items in the classroom based on your description using location words.
What are two objects that are near each other? What is in front of something else?

To simplify the activity, play one round without a curtain in place, describing positions and then having children recreate the arrangement while looking at your model. Once children have more practice, continue playing with the curtain in place.
Add a third Connecting Cube to the arrangements you are making behind the curtain, and include
as a location word. Provide a description of the locations of all three cubes.
Demonstrate each of the location words you will be using with a corresponding model of Connecting Cubes, including
on, beside, near, far, in front of,
To use gross motor skills and get children moving, have them recreate the arrangements with their bodies and colored blocks instead.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
For this activity, you will need Pattern Blocks in a variety of colors to use as vegetables for a garden and a large sheet of paper to use as the base for the garden.
we read about what happens in each season, as well as different things people like to do during the different seasons. In spring, people plant gardens.
Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

In this activity, we will imagine that these Pattern Blocks are different types of vegetables. We will discuss where we want to plant each vegetable, and I will plant it on our paper. I might make a mistake though! If I make a mistake, raise your hand to let me know.
Let’s start with carrots and peas. This Pattern Block is our carrots, and this Pattern Block is our peas. I want to plant the carrots
Lay out the “carrots” and “peas” next to each other rather than stacked. Check to make sure children’s hands are up.
Did I make a mistake? Where should I have put them? How can you tell?
Continue the activity, sometimes placing the blocks correctly and sometimes making mistakes. When you make a mistake, always ask children to explain why.
Ask children how they were able to catch your mistakes.
Was it ever difficult to tell whether I made a mistake or not? What words did you listen for to tell if I made a mistake?

First, model placing Pattern Blocks in different ways using correct location words to describe how the blocks are arranged. Guide children to repeat the descriptions after you. Then, reset to a blank garden and ask children to listen for and correct any mistakes.
After you have completed a garden, have children describe the relationships between the locations of multiple vegetables using location words.

Children can share the names of vegetables, fruits, and flowers in their home languages. You may also wish to review various location terms with children, using gestures with each word to illustrate the meanings.

Instead of planting the garden using Pattern Blocks, children can help you draw and color in each vegetable. Be sure to outline in pencil, so that you can erase mistake placements and reposition them before coloring them in.
